description.text:
This is a very similar design to my iPhone 4s Slim Case Blank. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:51533
I chopped, stretched, and massaged it until it fits like a glove! Use this as a clean slate for your custom things. Post pictures if you make one, and please let me know if you have any problems.
I have also included a version with holes that expose the Apple and iPhone logos on the back of the phone.

Print this with:
.20 mm layers
4 shells total
raftless with no support
230 / 110 temp
80 / 150 speed I print it from the "High" quality setting in Makerware, and just change the infill, shells, and layer height. You may need to do some very slight post print sanding, and then just wipe it down with a paper towel with a bit of acetone to give it back it's shine. You have to slide the top of the phone in first, and then snap the bottom sides around the phone. Removal is the reverse.

comments.text: Holes are smaller than logos.  Gaps around cut outs.

description.text:

See this thread for more information
http://voltivo.com/forum/davinci-firmware/239-cooling-fans-for-extruded-plastic-and-the-tool-head This piece is a redesign from another thing.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:433148 UPDATE!!! I have added a modified version of the Anchor. It has been extended to make it compatible with this E3D upgrade. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:744356 UPDATE. I modified both Anchors so they are easier to snap onto the Cooling Fan Shroud.

Print both pieces without support. They should snap together then snap to the front of your tool head. The Extended Anchor is for the people who have upgraded their Da Vinci 2 with the E3D v6 hot ends using this mod. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:744356

description.text: A lamp I made in the shape of the 34th Stellation of an Icosahedron.  This is actually the same shape as my "Star".  You might find more of the idea of the geometry of this lamp by looking at the "Star".

The skeleton is made of metal rods I soldered together. To that I glued rice paper. And of course inside is a light. I made one "spike" removable so that the light bulb can be changed in the future.
The underlying model I built using the instructions I tried to spell out under my "Star" model.
Once the cardboard model was built I cut the copper rods. I attached a scan of my notes for the rods. Their lengths are exact relative to each other, but their final lengths depend on how large of a lamp you want to build. Another scan gives you more of an idea of what that final length might be.

comments.text: I'll add some files, but I've got to make some first :-P  Everything that I've done so far has been pretty old-school; I'll have to scrape up my notes.  In the second picture you can see the cardboard model I made and then taped the cut rods in place before I soldered them all together.

author: Signmaker

title: Filament Guide for Da Vinci printers

description.text: This little guy helps guide the filament from the drive gears into the threaded throat on the Hot end.  Without this little guy soft filaments can bend and escape out the small gap.  Please read the Instructions for more information.

Print this guy upside down with some Brim so it will balance properly. Then use a dremel to smooth it out and make it a perfect fit.
I was able to use this to print some rubber like filaments like Soft PLA and Ninja flex for a few seconds or minutes. But the Da Vinci hot end has too much of a heat creep issue. The heat builds up higher and higher in the throat until the filament jams. Poor design. Only way I know to fix it to replace the Hot ends with the E3 v6. I am working on that soon for the Da Vinci 2.0.

When you remove the tail rack on a BMW F650, there are these two holes left in the bodywork. This is my attempt to cover those.  
The challenge with 3D printing these is getting the "upright" angle just right. You've got to trade off making the posts (they want to be straight up or down) while keeping the outer shell still cosmetically acceptable.  
L & R sides are mirrors of each other.

description.text:
This is rail car number seven in what (I hope) will be a series of ten, one published every two weeks until Christmas. This O gauge car (wheels, axle, coupler and bed are all 3D printed plastic) is part of an active train.
First, you must build "Motorized Perseverance" by gzumwalt

This is high profile, so clear out any low hanging branches and take it for a ride.

This printrbot print bed platform and base starts with Beardface's printrbot bed ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17717 ) and incorporates a three point leveling system using the leveling knob idea from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9094 (reimplemented as an OpenSCAD file), but using a 3-point leveling approach. The bed platform and base are designed to be cut out of 1/4" MDF using a laser CNC printer. The spinner knobs can be 3D printed from ABS or PLA. Caveats:

  • Since the leveling system uses two layers of MDF with at least 1/4" spacing in between (for the two nuts and a little space for leveling) this system will reduce your printable Z-height by about 1/2" or a little more.

  • The holes for attaching the print bed to the bed platform are spaced for clipping an 8"X8" bed to the base from the outside. If your heated bed attaches via holes in the corner, the 4 holes for attaching it may need to be adjusted. The SVG file included can be edited using InkScape ( http://www.inkscape.org ).

Bill of Materials:
Original parts from PrintrBot
3 #6 panhead machine screws 1 1/4" to 1 3/4" in length.
9 (optionally 12) nuts to fit the screws. Standard or 1/2 height jam nuts are fine
the bed platform, cut from 1/4" MDF or plywood
the base, cut from 1/4" MDF or plywood
6 copies of the spinner knobs The holes and knobs are scaled to use 3 #6 panhead machine screws and nuts to attach the bed platform to the base. It attaches to the existing printrbot Y axis connectors and belt holders. Print out 6 copies of the spinner knobs: three fit above the base and three underneath. Nine nuts are used: 1 on each screw immediately below the top platform and one each above and below the base. The first nut holds the screw firmly to the bed platform, and nut and spinner knob above the base is used to adjust the height, and the lower spinner locks the platform firmly to the base. If desired, the top nut can be locked with threadlock, a 4th nut added to use as a jamnut, or it can be left alone (perhaps with an occasional retightening, if needed). For my bed, the layers are as follows (from top to bottom):
glass plate
heated bed
cork sheet

MDF bed platform (all the above held on to the MDF bed platform with clips in the corner)
uppermost nut, locking panhead screw to bed platform
upper spinner knob (with nut inside)
MDF Y-axis base
Y-axis mounts from original Printrbot, attached with original machine screws. Install the base and the bed platform such that the 2 leveling screws are to the front, and the single leveling screw is to the rear. To level:
Once installed, no tools are needed to adjust the level of the bed, the upper spinner knobs adjust the bed height and the paired lower spinner knobs allows one to lock the bed firmly to the base one leveled. Start by loosening the three lower spinner knobs. Then, using the upper spinner knobs, lower the bed on all three screws until the bed has 1/4" free space between the uppermost nut and the upper spinner knob. With the printhead to the front of the platform, use the upper front two knobs to level the bed left-to-right.
  • move the print head over (or even with) the first leveling screw, and adjust the Z stop. Move the head even with the othe front leveling screw and adjust til the height matches. If needed, readjust the 1st screw and repeat until both are level. Lock them in place by tightening the lower spinner knobs.
    • Once the front is zeroed in, move the printhead to the middle, then level the bed front-to-back using the third leveling screw and spinner knobs. Lock the rear knob once the bed is completely true.

I built this furnace so that I could easily cast 3D printed parts into exact cast metal replicas. With it I have cast high tolerance machine parts that required zero machining directly from 3D prints. Here is our documentary demonstrating the complete Lost PLA process with this furnace: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82176

Download the PDF. Note that any image in the PDF is enlargeable if clicked (and you are online). Note that this is more of an "instructable" than a "thing", but I think based on my successful Lost PLA 3D printed castings that it hopefully will have wide appeal to this community. I have documented the Lost PLA process used with this furnace design here (as featured on hack-a-day): http://3DTOPO.com/lostPLA.

description.text:
A few improvements over my first version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:528775). Now have an even better version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:733390) which can support more phones. Works best with a Note4 in an Otter Box enclosure. Works without the enclosure, but may require more adjustments. 1) Added 38mm and 48mm lens holders as an option
2) Increased the clearance around the nose for comfort
3) Increased the surface area for application of 3/4" weather stripping
4) Replaced the top strap fixture with a clip like the sides so you can easily remove the straps for hand-held operation. Now you need to print 3 instead of 2. (Sorry, I didn't touch the original STL so it still only contains 2 - print twice, keep the best 3). No need for supports. The magnet trigger remains quirky on the GC design. I have found that it seems to work well if, after dragging the magnet to the bottom of the slider, to continue to pull down - rocking the magnet counter-clocwise ~45 degrees. Update: I found a cheap supplier of nice, large (48mm) lenses: http://www.surplusshed.com/lens.cfm. Pick lens L7315 or L7128 (glass - for $4.50 each!) and print the bigger lens holder. For me, I have these new lenses all the way back at the stops as my eyelashes brush against them. Although it works for me (slightly near-sighted), depending on your prescription, you may not find that is sufficient. Stay tuned, I will likely produce an updated viewer with the phone a little farther away so the lenses can be farther from the eye allowing more flexibility.

I am somewhat a throwback with a rather prominent brow (as well as dragging knuckles) so I had to add an extra layer of weather stripping to the cheek lands to compensate.  More evolved specimens may find one layer each fits best.

comments.text: Yeah.  I tried the 35mm FL lenses today and, while they did allow me to wear my glasses, there was a lot of distortion.  I think to support glasses you will just need to stretch the body in the Z axis to make room.  You can do this in Repetier Host with the scale options.  Magnet may be a little loose, but other than that it should work.
comments.author: TickTock

comments.text: You want to pick a FL equal to the desired distance from the lens to the phone screen but be aware that the farther away from your eye, the more magnification (i.e. less visible screen area).  So to support glasses I guess you need a shorter FL to make room (move the lens further from the eyes and closer to the screen).  Just guessing here - not really strong on optics so you may have to experiment.  I use the 44mm FL (48.4mm diameter DCX) and my eyelashes brush the lenses but I think this is what you want (lens as close as is comfortable to your eye) to get the greatest immersion.  I found the elastic at a local craft store chain (Jo-Ann's).
comments.author: TickTock

comments.text: Great, thank you again.

I'm going to try to modify the case so that people with glasses can wear it comfortably. So, assuming vision isn't an issue, which lenses from Surplus Shed would you recommend?

One thought is to redesign the front so the phone can easily be removed without removing the goggles to facilitate operating the touch screen.  Second, I suppose I should look at making the magnet more reliable.  Any other suggestions?
comments.author: TickTock

comments.text: This is a problem plaguing all Google Cardboard designs - even the official kit offered by Google.  The magnet trigger, while clever, is unreliable.  Hopefully Google will come out with an update (maybe a calibration) on a future release.  Meanwhile, I have found I have success by rocking the slider rather than sliding it.  I pull it down to the bottom of the groove and then continue to pull down a little farther - rocking it counter-clockwise ~45 degrees.  This seems to work well.  I have been toying with redesigning the slider to hinge rather than slide to facilitate this but am reticent since I expect Google to fix the problem at some point.

description.text:
In my experience having a jam and fool-proof filament feeder system is a must for care-free printing.
This thing is instructions for building a horizontal, hung, filament supply system.
The only printed part is the swivel housing. It uses a common 624 bearing, some string, and a plastic (or anything cut-table)bowl or tray.

Print one Swivel bottom, making sure to extrude hot enough to get good layer bonding.  Insert a 624 bearing into it while it is still hot.
Insert an M4x40 socket head cap-screw into the bearing, and an M4x30 socket head cap screw through the side..
Find a bowl, bucket, or plant holder bottom, the right diameter, and tie it to the swivel with string. When everything is level, lock the string down with hot-glue.
Cut a smooth hole in the middle to feed the filament out of and find a place to hang it.
If it is located too high above the printer, there is a chanced that filament will 'auto-feed' out of it. So a guide located slightly below the feeder is a good idea, though not absolutely necessary, if you hang it low enough above the printer.

description.text:
Debido al polvo del ambiente y otros tipos de suciedad que hay en el aire, en las bobinas de hilo inevitablemnte siempre se acumula algo. Para que esa porqueria no entre dentro de tu extruders y lo atasque o algo peor... He echo este adaptador que se pone al principio de la linea de entrada que va hacia cada extruder. en mi caso dual.
Poner dentro algun tipo de espuma o tela, y cada cierto tiempo pues, reemplazarlo. //////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Due to ambient dust and other dirt in the air, wire coils inevitablemnte always builds something. For that crap does not fall within your extrudes and jam or worse ... I miss this adapter is put at the beginning of the input line that goes into each extruder. my dual case.
Put in some kind of foam or cloth, and every so often then replace it.

title: Modified Airtripper BSP Edition Extruder Body

description.text: This version of Airtripper's BSP Edition extruder has been modified to accommodate 4mm threads on a "4mm to M5" push fit connector.  The BSP hole has been enlarged and the width of the push fit housing has been reduced by 1mm to allow a snug fit.

description.text:
Printed for the IceboxChallenge!
    • *3d printed part pictures to be added soon. Currently printing parts now, wanted to make sure submission was in though. *More versions of dividers/circles to be uploaded soon. Dimensions of pegs will also soon be coming as detailed drawings, for those who want to design dividers/organizers. Modular Shelving units!!!
    • Keep the stuff in your fridge organized with these sweet modular shelves.
    Features easy to pull out drawers, configurable dividers & organizers, and a super sturdy design. Drawers can be configured and reconfigure with ease, just drop in your dividers to make any size section, or stick them on the front row and apply labels as needed! No more looking for lost jar, easily identify whats where. Also available are varying circle cutouts. This lets you easy keep jars, spices, pretty much anything round, in place as you pull out drawers. Bases can be stacked both up and down, and left to right. Drawers lock in only from the front, so when you pull a drawer out it doesn't come tumbling down!
    Bases come in multiple sizes, and can be used with a single spacer, to give you added height (Using the limited dimensions from IceboxChallenge)

Since these designs will probably at some point end up holding a decent amount of weight, I suggest using a high infill, 40% minimum to ensure parts don't break.  
Additionally, if you do decided to stack drawers, suggest putting heavy things on the bottom, to keep it from tipping forward. Same as any free-standing cabinet or drawer, it has its limitations. Can also glue shelving together if you do not plan on configuring the shelves, and only the drawers.
This is a holder for a Dremel extension shaft that can be screwed onto a magnet or a wall.
I made this as a beneficial print for bed leveling and calibration
I only print the first level, then remove the build plate, take it over to my granite slab and build a height map with a height gauge.

I have needed to quickly form hinges, just from printed parts.  Additionally, I want to have a standardized hinge to allow me to use the hing in any design, and ensure it mates with other pieces. 
This thing is one piece of such a system.  In this case, the basic hinge is attached to the standard Yazzo UClip.  The default size is that of the MakerBot plywood.
The design is such that the pieces will simply snap together and rotate around a dimple/indentation.  that's nice because it does not require a pin, or any other hardware.  Just the printed pieces.
The easiest use you could put this to is to attach a couple of clips to the edge of a MakerBot window, then attach another couple of clips to a piece of acrylic, roughly the size of the window.  You get instant "doors" for your MakerBot.

1) Print a few hinged clips
2) Attach the clips to things
3) Snap the hinges together
4) Rejoice! The hinge is meant to print in opposites. That is, if you have two of the hinges, you have to flip one of them to mate with the other. This is by design as it requires only one hinge half, not two different ones.

title: Male and Female Threads Generated With stl_threads

description.text:
Created with stl_threads and other stl_cmds.
Printed on my Makerbot Replicator 2. Read more about how this was created in my blog post.

stl_cmd is a suite of command line tools for manipulating binary STL files. stl_threads can generate screw threads per the ISO metric thread standard. Unlike OpenSCAD solutions that perform many, many slow CSG operations, stl_threads directly generates the triangles necessary to represent the threads. Any resolution/configuration is pretty much instantly generated. This file was created with the following commands: stl_threads -D 8 -P 2 -h 20 -a 90 male.stl stl_threads -f -D 9 -P 2 -h 20 -a 90 female.stl stl_transform -tx 15 male.stl male_transformed.stl stl_merge -o threads.stl male_transformed.stl female.stl Documentation for stl_threads. stl_threads [ -f ] [ -D <diameter> ] [ -P <pitch> ] [ -a <angle> ] [ -h <height> ] [ -s <segments> ] <output file> Outputs an stl file with male or female screw threads per the ISO metric
screw thread standard. -f - Outputs female threads (defaults to male). -D <diameter> - Changes to major diameter of the threads. -P <pitch> - Changes the height of a single thread, aka the pitch per the ISO metric standard. -h <height> - Changes the total height of the threads. -a <angle> - Changes the thread angle (degrees). The standard (and default) is 60 degrees. For 3D printing this can cause overhang issues as 60 degrees results in a 30 degree angle with the ground plane. Setting to 90 degrees results in a 45 degree angle with the ground plane. -s <segments> - Changes the resolution of the generated STL file. More segments yields finer resolution. <segments> is the number of segments to approximate a circle. Defaults to 72 (every 5 degrees).

comments.text: Thanks for sharing this. The command line package looks interesting too. Imported these into my editor and it looks like the normals were all correct too. :)
comments.author: jsprenkle

comments.text: You're welcome! Yeah, I was diligent with my vertex ordering and normal calculations. BTW, in the stl_cmd suite there's an stl_normals which can check the stored normals vs calculated normals of the triangles and will tell you if they match or not. It also can reverse normals and fix the normals if they're different than the actual normal of the triangles.
comments.author: jsprenkle

title: Flamewheel F450 600 TVL FPV Camera Mount

description.text: This is a camera mount for a fatshark 600 TVL camera that easily mounts to the Flamewheel F450. The 4 mounting holes on the bottom line up with the slots at the front and back of the F450. The 600 TVL camera rests in a cradle and is affixed using a 2.5mm zip tie that goes through a slot underneath.

I printed this on a MakerGear M2, I used 3 shells, so infill did not come into play. Place the camera into the cradle with the lens fitting through the large hole. A 2.5mm zip tie should secure the camera to the cradle. There is a slot located just under the camera to accommodate the zip tie. This should mount to the slots on the front or back of the bottom plate of the F450 frame. You can mount the camera on the top or bottom of this plate.

I designed this old school Gramophone as a proof of concept. Printing just a .20mm thick diaphragm, with the help of a sharpened needle you can play any spinning vinyl. The sewing needle vibrates from the spinning vinyl. That vibration is transferred to the diaphragm, which emits the sound you hear. This design is just a proof of concept. I bet someone with better design skills than myself can put together a full working version. Video of Sound: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Zla9m8eeLQ Disclaimer: The needle will potentially damage your records. Do not use with your treasures. I picked up some cheap Beethoven from Goodwill for $1. I recommend the same. Needles are needles. Therefore sharp. I recommend a good set of pliers to assemble.

1) Print Gramophone and cover.
2) Sharpen a sewing needle that will fit into the assemby.
3) Place gently on a spinning record.
4) Delight in the sound.

author: smithd

description.text:
Useful for keeping wires from tangling up when put into storage.  
I have no association with Microsoft and just used their logo and name to save some material and make it more aesthetically pleasing.

comments.text: That's not the right logo.
comments.author: mhoyledesign

comments.text: Will this work for the Surface Pro 4 as well?  Wasn't sure if the brick charger was the same size.
comments.author: rsghowellnj

comments.text: I believe it is.  I had a Surface Pro 3 and just got a Surface Book and they look to be the same size.  I'll know in about 2 hours :-)
comments.author: rsghowellnj

comments.text: Thanks
comments.author: mattkins99

comments.text: My first print attempt failed and on my second attempt I printed the remix where it's in two parts.  the charger fits in the holder but it sticks out about 2mm and the holes don't line up.  So, just FYI.
comments.author: rsghowellnj

comments.text: Okay then ... thanks ... I guess my search continues for something better on the Surface Pro 4 Charger
comments.author: mattkins99

comments.text: How was this printed with out supports? It's a gift and I want to make sure it fits and looks great
comments.author: Thebak3

comments.text:
I used a more advanced printer that printed supports that could be melted away. There is a remix of the design that splits the enclosure into two parts. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:808933
Check it out!
comments.author: Thebak3

comments.text: was this made in metric or us standard? (mm or in)
comments.author: ice876

comments.text: I reuploaded the file so it should be the right size now. Before it was scaled down too much.
comments.author: Thebak3

comments.text: Ok I'll give it another try tonight
comments.author: ice876

comments.text: I printed this in 2 pieces, but the issue i ran into was the words and the windows logo, Everything on the sides collapsed and i didn't add support between letters. Any printing advice here?
comments.author: Sallen1215

comments.text:
I just wanted to print this, but it's a little smaller than my power adapter...
It's about 4mm (0.15'') long from USB to AC socket in all of my programs.
Please upload it in the correct scale or tell me how wide the walls should be.
comments.author: Horstage

comments.text: The one I made fits perfectly.  Scale up by 25.4.  I am guessing it was designed in inches and exported in millimeters.  It is a nice design.
comments.author: Horstage

comments.text: I want to print this!!
comments.author: kaotot
